yn 1982. I've always been a fundraiser but Mick has always been on the, on the, on the,

felt about it. To St. Christopher's Hospice. You went to St. Christopher's Hospice, didn't
you? Yeah, St. Christopher's Hospice down there. With Dame Cicely Saunders. They said,

had it. The other way round, we raised the money and then we put it into a building
and the building was just up the Haven Road there. That's where we were first. But what inspired
people to raise money and support the charity was the memory of Father Sartori. Yes, yeah,
that's right. Well, I think, I hope we're not going to try to make him into a saint because
he wasn't a saint. He was a very ordinary man and realistic in knowing what was needed.

gone. That's why it's now a hospice at home. Well, we had various speakers over the years.

where they have a hospice, I think. And they advised us and Prue Clentz from the Dorothy
House Foundation was very good at telling you about things about taking a birthday cake
into somebody's home. It sounds ridiculous to, you know, well, OK, they could do that
themselves, but no simple things. And people being allowed to have their dog with them
and that sort of thing, which are very important. And I think they brought us to see that it
was the actual care. And I know with Carmel, when my friend Joe was dying in St. Thomas's
in London, Carmel was the liaison, you know, and I have known all my life that I could
turn to Carmel and say, can you tell me anything about Joe? And she'd say no. Or she'd say
she's getting to come home on this side, but she would only tell you what she was allowed
to tell you. But she could liaise between St. Thomas's Hospice and the hospital here
and the nurses here. And that made such a difference. You know, I wonder what
I found that Paul Sartori would think of the charity now.
